description: {"blocks":[{"key":"bahtf","text":"Photogrammetry is a method of calculating the three-dimensional shape of an object from a set of images. The advantages of Photogrammetry include the ability to record the shape of an object in a short time and with high accuracy without contact. In addition, the generated model can be displayed without textures. Here, the High Resolution Photogrammetry method is presented, which describes the use of photogrammetric techniques to take pictures and generate models. This method aims to give a comprehensive and extensive description for the development of high resolution 3D models, merging the well known techniques used in academic and computer graphic fields, allowing anyone to independently produce high resolution and quantifiable models for any need.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"5sb6h","text":"In the following protocol, typographical emphases and brackets have been used for software and in-text references.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4cacv","text":"They are: (1) main sub-steps and softwares in bold, e.g. Add imagery and Adobe Photoshop; (2) \"software functions\" in \"quotation marks\", e.g. \"Copy correction settings\"; (3) \u003ckeyboard buttons\u003e in \u003cangle markers\u003e, e.g. \u003cright click\u003e or \u003cDel\u003e.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":57,"length":11},{"style":"bold","offset":73,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"o8iv","text":"Collect and prepare equipment.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ejgvr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7dd0e","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8ciru","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"arqmt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"48fuj","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"epmrp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"7E39B4403D7D11ECB1FC11756B911184","height":247.90181818181804,"id":188455,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2g5qi","text":"See Materials section for full list of equipment used in this protocol.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2ra7f","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/jpeg","original_name":"2.jpg","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2bjbgrsx.jpg","shadow":true,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2bhbgrsx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2bibgrsx.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2bgbgrsx.webp","width":466.93835616438344}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6d07r","text":"Generally, the use digital cameras, light boxes, and a turntable for photography are preferred. Nevertheless, in recent years the quality of cell phone photos has increased, and there are several Photogrammetry softwares on iPhone systems that can be used to scan easily. However, due to the limited image quality, scanning with mobile phones is not suitable for accurate scanning that requires less than millimeter accuracy.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"safety","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4mcvo","text":"If using a cell phone, scans will never be as accurate and precise and they could be when using a digital camera. Although not impossible to use a cell phone, this method has been developed to achieve the highest possible resolution for 3D models, making cell phones not suitable for this purpose.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2hgup","text":"Place the object on the turntable or holder, make sure it is centered on the turntable. The whole object should always be within the frame of the camera. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"389q8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ccsm","text":"Press the shutter by remote control and rotate the turntable. Repeat this operation until it rotates one circle. The angle of rotation can be smaller depending on the details of the subject. Ideally, a minimum of 18 times per rotation is preferred.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"45t3g","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5pse3","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1ejgg","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8djna","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"edl64","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"317317D03D7F11ECB1FC11756B911184","height":263.92000138716264,"id":188459,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"cura2","text":"Example of lithic artefact on holder. Note the marking every 45° on the base, with relevant  0° point at the base of the turntable.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/jpeg","original_name":"FBgF4WnWUAE4lMs.jpg","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2bpbgrsx.jpg","shadow":true,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2bmbgrsx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2bnbgrsx.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2bkbgrsx.webp","width":384.0105840289405}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"aq1q3","text":"If the object cannot be rotated, the object can also be placed in the middle of a table, with the photographed rotating and scanning 360° around the object. This requires a strong light source, and it is suggested to use a strobe mounted on the camera. This method is commonly used and it will provide a very quick photo process. However, because it is done manually by a person, there will be quality deviations between photos.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6rd2l","text":"Set the camera on a tripod.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"20ag8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ad7e3","text":"Choose a solid color for the background if possible (Black or white is recommended).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f44k0","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"av7ci","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"192a0","text":"Please note that the camera support greatly depends on the surroundings where the photographic station has been set up. Tripods work best on open spaces. On tighter spaces, photography arms with a clamp to attach to stable surfaces (such as tables) are more suitable.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"e8f56","text":"Set the turntable on the table and set the items you want to scan on it, placing at central as possible.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ddl81","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ee2p7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5o8ui","text":"It is recommended to use the remote control shutter to avoid shake. If the camera does not include one, remote control can be accessed via WiFi or Bluetooth; both Android and iOS universal applications exist for this purpose.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9a6qt","text":"If the object can be rotated and then reset on the turntable (as per a spheric object), rotate the object slightly at each rotation and repeat for one cycle. Repeat rolling and photographing until the object has been photographed from all 360 degrees.This usually requires an object that can rotate or supplemented by a stand that can support it.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e5gud","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"70krf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"afrm4","text":"Ideally, more rotations are photographs of the object the better it will be. The rotations should be envisioned as a full equally distanced \"sphere\" of photographs around the object. Consider 5 as a minumum number of rotations for a high quality final model.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"f39f3","text":"Open DxO Photolab (image processing software). You can also choose Adobe Photoshop, Adobe Lightroom or Capture One.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9cit","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"et41c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7jc89","text":"When processing RAW photographs, LibRaw can also be used, which is completely free and commonly used. However note that this software but requires some programming skills to make it work automatically with a large number of photos. It also requires post color calibration.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cb6ms","text":"If using a turntable, lighting for photogrammetry does not need to be completely uniform (360 degrees), but you need to keep the front lighting as uniform as possible. Diffused lighting is also recommended.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dhg63","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b5ajb","text":"Ring lights are a good choice, but you can also choose 2 or more LED lights set on the left and right sides of the camera.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b6p90","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bps04","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"35gnh","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3u1gn","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1reil","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fipc","text":"Ring flashes (such as the Godox Witstro AR400) will give efficient and bright lighting, however are somewhat expensive. LED lights are not bright enough however they are very cheap.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"26CE71403D7E11ECB1FC11756B911184","height":288.82907010165127,"id":188467,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bdbg2","text":"Example of front, diffused lighting.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/jpeg","original_name":"1.jpg","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2bxbgrsx.jpg","shadow":true,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2bvbgrsx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2bwbgrsx.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2bubgrsx.webp","width":304.3218171569122}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c4s54","text":"If the object can't be rotated properly, change the height and position of the camera so that the camera looks up at the object and take photographs in a circular motion. Repeat this action and finally flip the object up and down to take the bottom half.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bdisr","text":"RAW format (CR2, CRW, NEF, PEF...) is usually preferred For photogrammetry, this will provide a wider color gamut and more correct color calibration in post-processing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6rk6d","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"87f8u","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7nbem","text":"If high resolution of color and final model is not of importance, JPG/JPEG formats can also be used resulting in a more convenient and faster option.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"djc53","text":"Manual mode is usually selected because we want to have no difference in brightness during photography.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9qr9u","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8bg5u","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8nlli","text":"Manual mode is always suggested to use for photogrammetric purposes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7pt8h","text":"Changing the brightness does not change the model generation results to a certain extent, however, it directly affects the texture generation. For some items with extreme contrast, brightness can be changed at times during the process, but will require some practice to use this effectively.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"beerh","text":"Aperture.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6fdf8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cdai6","text":"Regular Photogrammetry usually selects an aperture between F/5.6 and F/16. Different aperture sizes depend on the focal length and the size of the subject. Too small aperture will cause diffraction and reduce the quality of the photo, while too big aperture will reduce the depth of field.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bn5k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d5adb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2bgqr","text":"For small items, aperture of around F/16 should be selected in most cases.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"989c9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ammat","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ans7a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":14,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"88j15","text":"Depth of field can be calculated according to the set aperture. Depth of field can be calculated from the focal length, distance to subject, the acceptable circle of confusion size and aperture .","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7fg8u","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":26,"offset":42,"style":"bold"}],"key":"6r2v2","text":"The object should always be placed in the middle of the camera frame, which indirectly determines the distance from the camera to the object, as well as the depth of field.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"808sd","text":"Exposure. Setting exposure time and ISO","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"607bg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"75n4e","text":"First set ISO to an optional value such as 200. Call up the histogram in the camera and try to shoot the object. Adjust the exposure time to the appropriate time so that the vertical part of the histogram representing the subject is in the middle and the highlighted part of the histogram.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cmtg3","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"81aa","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a0k7t","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ai6f3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4dnol","text":"If you are using LED lighting, the exposure time will usually be very long at this time. Reduce the exposure time and or you can increase the ISO value slightly. Until the ISO does not cause too much noise in your photos and the exposure time is at an acceptable value (too long an exposure time can make the photography process too long).","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3qa80","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6lksb","text":"If you use flash light, this adjustment will become easier.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8vj8","text":"However, I usually recommend using at least ISO200 instead of ISO100, because ISO200 does not cause much noise and will provide a shutter speed of one stop.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"safety","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"47c3q","text":"If the photo is very dark, a lower ISO will not make the overall noise less, as the noise in the dark areas will be amplified when the exposure is increased in post-processing.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9nrd4","text":"Set white balance.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"533vj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"feo7h","text":"You can set an arbitrary white balance when taking pictures and adjust it in post-processing. If possible, use a gray card or color checker and adjust the white balance based on it in post-processing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fbub6","text":"Advanced methods of measuring exposure.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":39}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8ge0q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2tn0p","text":"As the in camera histogram shows a preview image in JPG format, exposure should be directly evaluted on the RAW format photograph.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ucsb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bk91n","text":"After taking a photograph, decoduing of the RAW photo to check the photograph's exposure is required.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"276tr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ikhc","text":"To do so, Rawdigger can be used. To open a RAW photo on Rawfigger, hold down SHIFT to frame the object. Select","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"752jq","text":" on selection at the top left to select the histogram.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4321c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6ntqv","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dbo48","text":"The following exposure method was developed following enhancement of the methods explicated in sources 7 and 8 (before start section).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9fd7r","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9ijan","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6hlpt","text":" this photo,  the stone artefact is basically above EV-0, making it correctly exposed.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"1.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2b3bgrsx.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2bzbgrsx.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2b2bgrsx.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2bybgrsx.webp","width":534.7030716723551}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"29k3i","text":"If you are interested in the correct representation of the colours in the final model, Color Checker can be used, making sure that both colorchecker and object are correctly exposed. (Or adjust the exposure multiplier by calculation, which is slightly more complicated).","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"safety","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ah6bh","text":"It is important to note that the method we will describe for processing photos does not correct for color. In the case where perfect color wants to be represented, Cross-Polarization needs to be adjusted, followed by very complex correction in post-processing. These steps are not explicated in this protocol, as perfect color representation falls outside the scope of this method, and it will add further steps to the protocol.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7od7c","text":"For more detailed explanations on aperture, depth of field, exposure and white balance see - Cerasoni \u0026 do Nascimento Rodrigues (2021). \"Small Object and Artefact Photography - 'SOAP' Protocol\" - dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.buz8nx9w","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":34,"length":8},{"style":"bold","offset":44,"length":14},{"style":"bold","offset":60,"length":8},{"style":"bold","offset":73,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":196,"length":41}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"77F415D9460D11ECB1660A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.buz8nx9w"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5o05a","text":"When changing the height of the camera, it can also be moved closer to the obhect. This will make the distance between the camera and the object consistent.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2e9e9","text":"It is recommended to include a scale in the photographs of the selected object. Ideally, the scale should be fully visible in at least 4 or 5 of the photos so to aid in the allignment of all the photographs.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5qu7f","text":"General photography methods and ideas.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":38}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dc70k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4v3ec","text":"Because the basic way of photogrammetry's three-dimensional reconstruction is parallax, we need to take at least 2 photos of each surface of the subject. Therefore, before beginning the process, consider the following when photographing:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9op7l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"86j43","text":"1. Imagine a regular polyhedron (e.g., a regular dodecahedron) and place the subject in its center. Subdivide the polyhedron so that each vertex of the subdivision will be the ideal camera position, with each camera facing the center.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3aohi","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bi92g","text":"2. Imagine a simplified object, place the camera vertically facing all the simplified faces, and all the edges for the shot.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ap2ee","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"blqkj","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"at7nd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"077DBFC0461211EC82FA55188DB8E92C","height":268.13454059947605,"id":188475,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ucr","text":"Example of dodecahedronal perspective.
